contents.item: Do not lose yourself in the past. Do not lose yourself in the future. Do not get caught in your anger, worries, or fears. Come back to the present moment, and touch life deeply. This is mindfulness.
contents.owner: Thich Nhat Hanh, The Heart of the Buddha's Teaching: Transforming Suffering into Peace, Joy, and Liberation

contents.item: To "know" reality you cannot stand outside it and define it; you must enter into it, be it, and feel it.

contents.item: The mistake is to assume that the way it feels at the moment is the way it will feel forever.

contents.item: The energy of mindfulness has the element of friendship and loving kindness in it.

We do so much, we run so quickly, the situation is difficult, and many people say, "Don't just sit there, do something." But doing more things may make the situation worse. So you should say, "Don't just do something, sit there." Sit there, stop, be yourself first, and begin from there.

Working rightly, the brain is the highest form of "instinctual wisdom." Thus it should work like the homing instinct of pigeons and the formation of the foetus in the womb - without verbalizing the process of knowing "how" it does it. The self-conscious brain, like the self-conscious heart, is a disorder, and manifests itself in the acute feeling of separation between "I" and my experience.
contents.owner: Alan W. Watts, The Wisdom of Insecurity: A Message for an Age of Anxiety

contents.item: Meditation is to be aware of what is going on: in your body, in your feelings, in your mind, and in the world.

The standard way of reducing stress in our culture is to put as much energy as possible into trying to arrive at a moment that matches our preferences. This ensures that we feel some level of stress until we get there (assuming we ever will) and worse, it makes the present moment into an unacceptable place to be.

By learning to allow different types of discomfort to simply stay in the room with you, without your scrambling for a button to push (real or metaphorical), you make discomfort matter less.The pool of things you’re afraid of shrinks. It becomes a lot less important to control circumstances, because you know you can handle moments of uncertainty or awkwardness or disappointment without an escape plan.
Stay present, stay conscious.
Mindfulness is intimacy with all things.
You are a miracle. Remind yourself often.
contents.owner: Charnita Arora, Mindfulness for Beginners in Plain English: Practical Guide with Mindfulness, exercises & tips for anxiety and stress management

contents.item: To still your mind , first still your tongue.
If you must look back, do so forgivingly. If you must look forward, do so prayerfully. However, the wisest thing you can do is be present in the present... gratefully.

...but we're not being educated in how to be, only in how to accomplish. So it's all about acquisition, about getting stuff we don't have...As soon as you realize it's a thought pattern, you can write yourself a restraining order.
If you have mindfulness, if you feel safe, you recognize that you have plenty of conditions to be happy already, and that you don't need to run into the future in order to get a few more conditions.
contents.owner: Thich Nhat Hanh, Good Citizens: Creating Enlightened Society

contents.item: I would like people to remember of me, howinexhaustible was her mindfulness.
Mindfulness promises a great number of desirable benefits, and is based on much more solid research than many competing ideas on how to change people.
contents.owner: Paul Gibbons, The Science of Successful Organizational Change: How Leaders Set Strategy, Change Behavior, and Create an Agile Culture

contents.item: The important thing in our understanding is to have a smooth, free-thinking way of observation. We have to think and to observe things without stagnation. We should accept things as they are without difficulty. Ou mind should be soft and open enough to understand things as they are. When our thinking is soft, it is called imperturbable thinking. This kind of thinking is always stable. It is called mindfulness.
contents.owner: Shunryu Suzuki, Zen Mind, Beginner's Mind: Informal Talks on Zen Meditation and Practice
